lg.l:
MS VIII, 43-45]
I weary for the torrent leaping from off the scars [steep face of rock on mountainside] rough crest My muse is on the mountain sleeping My harp is sunk to rest
I weary for the fountain foaming for shady holme [flat land near river, tending to flood; northern/Scottish word] & hill My mind is on the mountain roaming My lyres voice is still.
I weary for the woodland brook that wanders through the vale That I weary for the heights that look adown upon the dale
The crags are lone on Conistone [sic] & Glaramaras Loweswaters dell And dreary on the mighty one The cloud enwreathed Scawfell Oh what although the crags be stern Their craggy peaks that sever Fresh flies the breeze on mountain fern And free on mountain heather
There is [a(?)]1 thrill of strange delight That passeth quivering oer me When blue hills fade upon the sight Like summer clouds before2
Tis transient, as the snowy drift3 That passeth away4 [Its or Tis] like the blush of morn that swift Doth melt into the day
I long to tread the mountain head Above the valley swelling I long to feel the breeze fled5 From grey & gaunt Helvellyn.
I love the eddying circling sweep The mantling and the foam Of murmuring waters dark and deep Amid the valleys lone
It is a terror, yet tis sweet Upon some broken brow To look upon the distant sweep Of ocean spread below
1The word in ms. is unquestionably written as at, not a, but Ruskin probably unconsciously added the t in anticipation of the next word, thrill. 2Although demanded by the rhyme, me does not complete this line, as it does in John Jamesâ€™s editing. 3This stanza is roughly scored through in pencil by John James. 4These three words are widely spaced, as if Ruskin meant to fill in a word to complete the meter. 5Next to fled, John James wrote in pencil sped, which is the word used in 1850.
And sleeplessly counting the moments Hay
I thought of the joys that my bosom should know
Of the rich tides of pleasure unmingled which flow
Unmingled with grief and unmingled with gall
But draughts of delight rapture banquetings all
Impatient I watched as the lingering light
Too slowly overpowered the clouds of the night
Who clothed in her star sprinkled heaven shrouding vest
Which gracefully masked her er peaceful breast
And while on her brows her dark tresses among
Which flowed soft the pale crescent benignantly shone
From the earth cheering rays of Aurora she fled
In stern winter palaces hiding her head
At length the time came when the bill being made
Boots hostler and chambermaid all duly paid
Sticks bonnets hats greatcoats all duly prepared

sp.speaker: Antony
sp.l: I come to bury Caesar, not to praise him.
